plist.p: Good morning everybody, welcome to Geneva. Thank you for coming this morning. I appreciate your time. We have the Richemont financial year, 31st March 2009 results presentation. I'd like to introduce to you, this morning, Mr. Johann Rupert, our Executive Chairman; Mr. Norbert Platt, Chief Executive Officer; and Richard Lepeu, Chief Financial Officer who will be presenting to you on the results.
I could just use – make the usual comment about mobile phones. If you could make sure they're switched off, so that they don't interfere with the microphones and the Internet broadcast.
So welcome everyone. I hand you over now to Mr. Rupert, Mr. Platt and Mr. Lepeu.

Thank you, Alan. Good morning, everyone. You don't have to worry about your mobile phones, because there is no signal down here in any case. Alan, in case you haven't noticed. I see there are very few people here. I gather it's LVMH's general meeting today at the same time. Sorry.
And the Internet broadcast.

And the Internet broadcast. Well, what we feared over the past few years and communicated with you has clearly occurred. We do have a major economic contraction, a slowdown, a credit crunch, or as a friend of mine's blonde wife said we have a credit card crunch, which I thought was quite a beautiful description.

Now the bad news is it's real. Anybody who knows when it's got an end has got a line to the almighty that I do not have an extension too. Because I can assure you, we don't see any green shoots of recovery. And I'm talking across the world in all industries, people that I speak to, whether they be in the luxury automobile industry, whether they be – whether it be Sotheby's, Christie's, the wining people who sell on premier wines. And I think it's going to be with us for a while.

The good news is that we started quite a while to prepare Richemont for this eventuality, and as a result, due to the good work, Norbert, Richard and Gary Saage and all of our colleagues, we've got a very clean balance sheet and we have liquidity, both inside Richemont, and if I dare say, at the family company above Richemont, so that you will see in our dividends that even though Richemont's share over the year ago would have had – even despite the decline of sterling versus the euro, and translated into Swiss francs, if Richemont shareholder had kept the shares, he or she would have had a small increase in dividends even during these tough times.

And despite that small increase, you will notice that our dividend cover is still our normal prudent cover, which leads to the obvious conclusion that as in the past we're putting more money into the company to support the Maisons, where by the way you will see this little R, because we have actually registered our Maisons, because when Alain Perrin came with DNA and everybody started using . So, we actually – Frederick Mostert did register Maisons for us.

But this should give you confidence that we here, for the medium to long term, we're supporting the Maisons. The brand equity is supporting our colleagues. And during this period, however long it might take, we intend also looking on our service to our clients.

I think it's best summarized – one of our colleagues who runs Van Cleef, when Norbert and I asked him a while ago, over a year ago, to start looking at what happened during the Great Depression, they actually went a bit further and they looked at Van Cleef, and as he modestly said they're one of the younger Maisons in the Group, because they're only slightly over 100 years old. He said it seems that any 20 – every 25 years they have a crisis. So they had a crisis in the First World War, and our Founder, the Founder of Van Cleef went into – Van Cleef & Arpels went into the trenches. In line next to him in the trench was a gentleman, asked him what he is doing, he said I'm a jeweler. So they agreed that if they both survived the First World War that his new comrade would join him. Well, he joined, his son later on joined, his grandson joined and the great granddaughter is still with Van Cleef.

Then came the depression, obviously, less work. Well, they took their time and they perfected and – designed and perfected the famous Mystery Setting, which Van Cleef is still well renowned for. That was done at the height of the depression. Then the Second World War looming, they did another bright move and they moved to New York, and in 1959 they opened on 5th Avenue.

In the 4th, which most of the people in the room are too young to remember, but May '68 in Paris it was war. surround the capital city with tanks. And as you can imagine being a jeweler on Place Vendôme it was a crisis. So they used that crisis and they designed the Alhambra branch, which today is still one of the best sellers. To me that's a light motif for our Group.

We will use the resources – our human resources. We will enhance the quality of the product. We will further improve our relationships with our customers, and when this recession ends, hopefully, we would have improved our competitive position. So to reiterate, we are in a recession that we expected. I have no idea when it's going to end.

Luckily, we prepared for a very strong balance sheet, and as, I repeat, as a family we're liquid, so we do not have to rely upon dividends to service debt above the holding company, above Richemont, which is critical. We can therefore afford to leave the money in the company. Despite that we're fortunate enough that we could give our shareholders an improvement in their dividends.

And I thank all of my colleagues for their work, dedication. One additional comment, I was perturbed to read that Cartier was not doing well and that we're laying people off in Switzerland. Cartier had a record year and Cartier didn't fire anybody in Switzerland. A number of our Maisons are using the partial work system, which I actually admire, which by the way we paid for in the good years. So, yes, we will use this system that's at our disposal to balance supply and demand. But these people were not fired. They're still employed. And we have a partial system that you're all very aware of and familiar with.

Secondly, there were some scurrilous attacks on Jérôme Lambert of Jaeger-LeCoultre totally and utterly devoid of the truth, not only with the inflammatory, but they were based upon total lies. There were no supposed meetings between me and Norbert. We weren't even in the same time zone. We took the very unusual step of actually suing the Internet journalist. It's not a decision taken lightly, but when you have a colleague who has done exemplary work, who has built the Maison brilliantly, whose watch I'm proud to wear, and his kids have to hear lies at school, we will defend our colleagues. I don't know will – next year is going to be better. If you put $3 trillion into a society, into a system, it's bound to be abound somewhere. Hopefully in a year's time, you'll say that I was overly cautious, I doubt it, I think we're here for quite a while.
I'd like to hand it over to Norbert who will present the first section of the results. And then afterwards Richard and then afterwards we will be open for questions. Thank you.

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, here and on the web. I think actually my Chairman said everything, so we all can go home, unless of course you are analysts, you need to look at the figures, so let's look at the figures.

Well, this is a good result and it's a bit like – not interesting, because you will know – want to know, will it remain that good? Having said this, we have seen a very negative November-December. The decline somewhat slowed down to almost flat at the end of the last quarter. And therefore we are 2% higher than the year before, €5.4 billion.

Region-wise, again, not a surprise, contrasting too, not specifically big news, I guess. Asia-Pacific outperformed through the year. Americas showed the weakest and the United States is close to being dead right now.

Decline in operating profit resulted from the slowdown, but I think was reasonably contained at €982 million. In times like this, and the Chairman said it already, focus is on cash flow. And I think we have managed well to show a strong cash flow of €819 million with net cash ending at 822.

And let me tell you something. I mean last year when we met you around this time, we talked already about initial measures. We talked about the anticipation that things might change. We introduced at least in Japan and America measures to be careful to no more hire people early in the year last year. Quite frankly our colleagues start disguising the ivory tower are totally bananas, because we are still very optimistic.

Unfortunately, since October even our younger colleagues know that we were unfortunately right. This is shown again in this little chart here. Up till September the world seemed to be okay and a lot of people who have not come to live in business for 40 years like me, thought it's never ending. Half-year sales ended 10% up in euro terms. Since October, of course, and I don't want to bore you with the details, because we all know that financial markets went where they went and all feel-good factor therefore just disappeared like water on our plate. Feel-good factor is the key for our business.

Traveling is the key for our business, by the way. And quite frankly when things started in Mexico, I thought, oh my God, please no. And a week before, I saw a very interesting – I heard a very interesting philosopher talking about how you can force luck. And I thought, please not. So let's all touchwood that this crisis of the swine flu or the Mexico flu is contained as it looks right now.

We had obviously a poor Christmas season, which reported sales down 7% in September. As I said before, the last quarter ended somewhat less negative, down minus 1%. As a result, second quarter, as you can see there, ended down 5%.

Let me talk a bit about currencies. We have often said this, the Chairman said it here in various occasions before. Volatility of currencies, of course, is important for our global business. The last year was very interesting, because of course a stronger yen – a stronger euro means normal local price increases, higher purchases from non-residents in Europe and higher translation of results. The yen strengthened, it has strengthened since its weakest point, almost 20%, as I don't need to tell you, which is good for us. But then we saw a very weak dollar, all your colleagues expected it to go to two, and by the time you were absolutely sure it changed around again and has become stronger, which of course is difficult for the business to manage. It's impossible to manage. These are the things we cannot manage.

Prices for gemstones and precious metals had a similar curve. Last year it was almost impossible to buy stones. The price of gold, I don't need to talk about, because it went to the biggest peak ever. Meanwhile it went – every commodity, every materials went down to the very bottom. And it's on a upswing that as you know the price of oil yesterday touched again US$60, which again, is good for our business, because the Middle East is still one of the growth regions and we hope that this continues.

Again, this is a mixed environment. My Chairman has said everything what is there to be said. Richemont managed to deliver a strong set of results, we believe, and we are pretty confident we can weather this storm.

Thank you, Norbert, and good morning to you all. So let's start with sales. Sales in Europe, which includes the Middle East, remains our biggest region with 44% of Group sales. Sales rose by 5% at constant rates, with a decline of 8% in the last semester.

These results mask the strong performance in the Middle East, where sales grew by 49% at constant rates. Even in second half, sales continued to grow at similar levels. The Middle East contributes 6% of Group sales.

In Western Europe, sales declined by 1%. Sales with locals decreased, but increased with third-party nationals from Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Asia. We estimate that above 50% of sales in this region are now made with this clientele.

Asia-Pacific is our second region. Its weight has increased to 27% of Group sales. Sales rose by 14% at constant rates, the fourth year of double-digit growth. The growth rate, however, slowed down to 1% in the second half of the year. The performance was uneven among main markets.

Sales in Taiwan and Singapore were down, while in Hong Kong sales grew by 12% at constant rates, despite a challenging plus 39% achieved the previous year. In Korea, sales were even stronger, thanks to a return of Japanese consumers due to the appreciation of the yen.

In Mainland China, sales rose by 30% after plus 54 last year, confirming China as our number two market in Asia-Pacific after Hong Kong. In the last semester, sales grew by 11%. Mainland China has increased its contribution to Group sales to 6% and now ranks number five compared to seven a year ago. The yuan strength versus the euro, plus 13% over the period, has further boosted tourism of Mainland Chinese aboard.

Overall, we estimate Chinese from Mainland China, Hong Kong and Macau to account for more than 20% of Richemont sales. We view this clientele and region as strategic and the ones to outperform the rest of the world in the future.

The Americas region contributes 16% of Group sales and for the U.S. only 12% of Group sales. After seven years of double-digit rate growth at constant rates, sales momentum in the U.S. slowed in August, then negative in September. The trend worsened such that half-year sales ended March '09 down 30% at constant rates. For the year as a whole, U.S. sales declined by 12% at constant rates.

The only piece of good news was the appreciation of the U.S. dollar from August to March, which softened the decline of sales expressed in euro and stock price increases. Given the difficult environment and the cautiousness of our watch retailers, we maintain a negative view on this market. We have restructured the region by making people redundant and also looking at closing down 13 boutique in fiscal '10 out of a total of 90 internal boutique in the U.S.

Japan's contribution to Richemont sales only represents 13% of sales, but remains our biggest single country. Sales declined by 12% in yen, but only by 1% in euro, given the 11% appreciation of the yen over the period. Since its lows in July '08 the yen has risen by 28%, given the structural issues of Japan again, no CapEx and a streaming down of expenses will take place, certain boutique will be closed out of a network of 169. With the yen appreciation, we started seeing Japanese tourist returning to Korea, Hawaii and France. Overall, we estimate the contribution of the Japanese to worldwide sales in the order of 15%.

Looking at the constant currency sales by product line. We note that watch sales were flat, masking a notable performance from IWC, Vacheron Constantin and Jaeger-LeCoultre. The inflection in sales momentum has prompted us to reduce the Group's manufacturing output to limit a buildup of inventory at trade level.

Jewelry enjoyed the best performance, contributing €120 million in sales increase. The 9% constant currency growth rate reflects success at Cartier and Van Cleef & Arpels, particularly in high jewelry sales.

Leather sales were down five, despite positive developments at Montblanc. The reduction in sales of writing instruments reflects a difficult market, and sales in ready-to-wear and other went up by 9% as a result of the integration of Donzé-Baume, manufacturing company of watch cases.

Retail sales represents sales to our directly operated stores, they do not include sales to our franchise stores. The weight of retail is pretty much stable at 43% of Group sales. Its performance, plus 3% at constant exchange rate, was above wholesale. It's largely attributable to high jewelry sales and the impact of new stores. The wholesale performance reflects mostly the cautiousness of the watch retailers.

Here is our P&L. Sales grew at 2% in euro terms and at 1% at constant currencies. The IFRS operating profit decreased by 12% to €982 million. The decline was contained, thanks to a controlled growth in operating expenses and despite high non-recurrent charges that I shall detail in the next slide.

For the sake of clarity, here is a reconciliation of our operating profit. Starting with our reported IFRS EBIT of 982, I would like to remind you that it does not include the €30 million negative contribution of our discontinued businesses, namely the Montegrappa Maison and a small jewelry workshop.

If you want to obtain an underlying operating profit from continuing operation, you should add back the €79 million of non-recurrent charges. These charges consist of one-off cost of €40 million, such as the second SIHH and the reclassification of point-of-sales material in application of the new accounting principle IAS 38, as well as €39 million of restructuring charges consisting mainly of provisions for closing stores and social plans.

I also want to remind you, that we are benefited from more favorable exchange rates, which on the other hand have generated financial losses, realized and unrealized, which are reported under finance costs.

Gross margin – the gross margin rose to €3.4 billion, in percentage terms it lost 130 basis points to represent 63.3% of sales. This decline is a result of stronger Swiss franc, our precious material prices and the negative impact of lower production volume on manufacturing fixed cost, only partially offset by price increases.

As I explained earlier, we also benefited from favorable exchange rates, especially on the yen and the U.S. and Hong Kong dollars, which have somewhat compensated the appreciation of the Swiss francs. In this global negative context, Cartier and Baume & Mercier still managed to increase our gross margin percentage.

Net operating expenses grew by 7%, that was a 2% growth in sales. Excluding one-off expenses of €79 million, they grew by 3%. Selling and distribution costs, 50% of total OpEx, rose by 5%. The rise reflects primarily additional staff, leases and depreciation associated with the retail and wholesale network.

Communications costs were well controlled, taking into consideration the dramatic decline of sales during the Christmas season and the two watch Salon. As a result, the ratio was maintained at 11.9% of Group sales and for fiscal '10 we anticipate this ratio to remain broadly in line.

Administration cost increased by 4%, reflecting higher inflation rates around the world. Other income includes higher royalties from Chloé and a portion of the non-recurrent charges mentioned earlier.

The jewelry Maisons and the specialist watchmakers generated a contribution margin above 20%. The contribution of our jewelry Maisons and specialist watchmakers reached a high of 95% of Group EBIT before corporate expenses. This performance was partially offset by lower reserves as well, especially at Montblanc.
The jewelry Maisons sales grew by 4% at constant and reported rates, a notable performance given the environment and the very strong comparatives.
Let me remind you that sales grew at plus 16% at constant rates last year. The jewelry Maisons saw their contribution rise to €777 million, leading nevertheless to a 28% contribution margin.

Cartier posted a record year both in term of sales and profitability. This achievement underlines the resilience of its business, a balanced product offer and geographic coverage, including a successful penetration of emerging markets.

Van Cleef & Arpels profitability has continued to improve. Return on assets has declined due to higher inventories, but remains at a strong high level. Sales rose by 3% at constant rates for the segment of specialist watchmakers and by 4% in euros initially impacted by components shortages and lighter – and later by the softening of the watch market after years of extraordinary growth.

The specialist watchmakers saw their operating contribution decline to €287 million. The contribution margin went down to 20% of sales affected by slower sales, the strongest Swiss francs, the integration of Roger Dubuis, as well as the second SIHH.

With the exception of Roger Dubuis, all Maisons are profitable and generated a double-digit contribution margin, except for Baume & Mercier. IWC particularly stood out followed by Vacheron Constantin and then Jaeger-LeCoultre. Those three Maisons generated profits broadly in line with last year. The rise in net assets reflects our increased production integration, as well as a buildup in inventories and the acquisition of Roger Dubuis.

Following the decision to discontinue the operations of Montegrappa, these slides only relates to Montblanc both for fiscal '08 and fiscal '09. As expected, Montblanc price positioning and high exposure to an aspirational clientele made it more sensitive to economic slowdowns. The ongoing downsizing of this wholesale distribution network has put more pressure on its pens and wholesale businesses.

Despite a positive performance – plus America, more exposed to America – net of its exposure in Japan – despite a positive performance of its watch and leather business and on the phase of two years of strong double-digit growth at constant rates, sales declined by 7% at constant rates and by 6% in euros.

The evolution of the business model entailed higher working capital and investments in production and distribution. A review of the retail network was undertaken and led to the decision to close 11 underperforming stores in fiscal '09 and 23 in fiscal '10, mostly in the Americas and Japan. €7 million of restructuring charges have been allocated in this financial year.

Alfred Dunhill losses amounted to €2 million after a small profit last year. Dunhill has planned to close nine stores, including four in Japan. Restructuring charges in the current year amounted to €1 million. Lancel reported sales -
They made profits, but I actually thought that as part of building the they needed to have the two Maisons, their homes in Beijing.
Shanghai.

Sorry in Shanghai and in London and the club operates in London. And it's having the desired effect, but obviously there's a lead lag in terms of new concept, because they did make money. I think I went to Christopher Colfer, they made money before, there's nearly £2 million charge that – €2 million charge that fell between the two homes.

Lancel reported sales down 8%, therefore despite a higher gross margin percentage Lancel generated a loss of €8 million, up €4 million on last year. Lancel, we closed six stores, including four in Europe, incurring a €1 million restructuring charge.

Other businesses consist of fashion brands, primarily Chloé, as well as some non-branded components and manufacturing activities and other ventures. Sales rose by 3% at constant rates and by 6% in euro. Lower sales at Chloé were more than compensated for by the impact of the acquisition of Donzé-Baume. Losses include €6 million of restructuring charges, mostly due to our component manufacturing businesses, Chloé remaining profitable.

Net finance cost amounted to €101 million, primarily due to the mark-to-market accounting of our hedging program. It's obvious, as I mentioned, that we are benefiting directly in our gross margin of the favorable evolution of exchange rates. But because we maintain our policy of hedging, we have as a counterpart losses of hedging programs.

The lower reported tax rate of 15.7% reflects lower earnings and lower statutory tax rates in various jurisdictions. Net profit from parent and subsidiaries decreased by 23% to €748 million, representing 13.8% of Group sales.

Cash flow from operations reached over €800 million despite the sharp reversals in sales trend. Working capital increased by €361 million, primarily due to the increase in inventory. Inventory rose by €346 million due to lower sales, the acquisition of Roger Dubuis, network expansion and a stronger Swiss franc. The rise was mostly in finished goods. The stock rotation rate on gross inventory has gone from 16.4 months in March last year to 18.7 months this March. Inventory is monitored strictly and Norbert will give you more details later.

The collection of debtor balances is being tightly monitored and is slightly above last year relating to increased sales in the Middle East and China. The average recovery rates have not been impacted. Other items decreased as the funding of certain retirement benefits obligation did not recur in 2009 and charges on long-term incentive scheme declined.
Free cash flow from subsidiaries declined to €213 million due to higher CapEx and the acquisition of Donzé-Baume, a manufacturer of iron watch cases and the 60% of Roger Dubuis and other ventures.

We'll deal with CapEx in the next slide. The increase in tax payments reflects primarily payments accrued in the previous year. Richemont received for the last time a dividend from BAT amounting to €343 million, which was left with Reinet on the 20th of October 2008.
Gross fixed assets rose from 271 million to €305 million, accounting for 5.6% of sales. They were essentially targeted at growth markets, China and the Middle East, and the watch manufacturing needs.

Net fixed assets amounted to €293 million compared with a depreciation level of €175 million. For the year to come, we anticipate gross fixed assets to be around €165 million, which is more or less in line with the level of depreciation.

We will continue to invest in SAP, a new boutique in China primarily for Cartier with limited refurbishment as well and we'll continue to invest in two major manufacturing projects, Jaeger-LeCoultre extensions, which is nearing completion and Val Fleurier, the strategic watch components facility to mitigate potential supplies and risk rate of 2011 and address the increased demand for high-end in-house movements.

By segment, around 30% of the investments were made by the jewelry Maison and around 20% by the specialist watchmakers. By geography as planned, apart from the investment in manufacturing in Europe, most of the assets were made in Asia-Pacific and in the Middle East.

By nature, over 50% of our investment related to retail. The most notable retail investment during this year were Cartier boutique in Beijing Park Life, Seoul Cheonho-dong and Dubai Mall. Van Cleef & Arpels, Montblanc and Jaeger new stores in Dubai Mall and the Dunhill and Vacheron Constantin flagship in Shanghai. The majority of other relates to investment in our service platform and IT hardware. In manufacturing, over 30% of our investments, the most important investments, were the extension of the manufacturing facilities at Val Fleurier that I mentioned of Jaeger-LeCoultre and Cartier . It does not include the intangibles relating to R&D for watches.

Even after the cash payment of €438 million in ordinary dividend at the end of September '08 and the transfer of €351 million to Reinet of the 20 of October, Richemont's balance sheet remains very healthy. Inventory at €2.4 billion is our biggest asset, representing 33% of our total assets followed by cash 26% and fixed assets 21%. Our gross cash position amounts to €2 billion and our net cash position to 822. Equity represents 65% of our balance sheet.

Since 2007, the Group has adopted a very conservative stance for its cash resources by investing in funds of the highest-rated European government bonds, preferring safety to higher yields. At the end of March, close to €850 million were invested in such trends.

Operating cash is invested in the most highly-rated banks, while structural operational debt is primarily maintained in non-euro-denominated currencies. As explained earlier, the net profit contribution from parent and subsidiaries declined due to lower operating profit and a significant decrease in net financial income only partly compensated by lower taxes.
In this slide you can see the impact of the Group's restructuring, profit from BAT has been equity accounted until the 20th of October.

The 2009 dividend of CHF0.30 per share to be proposed to shareholders in September reflects the absence of any BAT dividend inflows. However, when taking into account the dividends to be received directly from BAT, a unique holder who has kept its BAT shares after distribution of Reinet would receive at least the same dividend as last year. The dividend will be fully paid in Swiss francs for the first time and will be subject to the 35% withholding tax.
Thank you. I now hand you to Norbert.

Okay. Ladies and gentlemen, besides the analysis of figures I gave you a little bit of an overview of how we handle this unprecedented crisis. I want to talk about these issues you see there in detail. Specifically, I think cash generation is one of our big focus for the period to come, however long that period might be.

We have quite early stopped overtime, because it's very obvious that any kind of excess in production leads finally to inventory levels, which are unhealthy even if you have some discipline in your own companies. We do not want to produce products particularly, watches which we cannot sell and even more important we don't want to overly push sales to watch retailers. As you all know that this has undesired and unintended consequences, the gray market being one of them.

As you have thought before, until September, the close of which has resulted that in most of our Richemont internal and external component manufacturers, we could not get enough product. We were unable to meet demand nothing particularly exciting for you to hear because last year that was the topic, what are you doing – topic from you, what are you doing to meet demand? How can you expand production? Which new factories are you building overnight?

Well, as we all know this demand stopped almost overnight and we introduced in October hiring freeze for all players. And I tell you, I live in a French environment, right and I love that French environment. However, when you stop hiring people, and even more, you tell that every hiring is now personally endorsed by the CEO himself. Some of my colleagues . Why do we do this? We want discipline. We want people to think twice before they replace or re-hire.

And of course, strategic positions we will re-hire, but not necessary everybody just by routine and impulse. So it's a disciplinary exercise who my HR Director saw this most, because he is the first guy who gets all the requests and he has to field the hunt; there was a time when I just chased him out of the office because I knew it would get worse.

We have maximized in-sourcing and minimized outsourcing. Unfortunately, our competitors do the same thing. You know that we are not only having brands, we have a number of factories which produce components for us and for other companies, including, of course, our competitors, one of the historical structures of Swiss watchmaking.

In dial manufacturer like Stern or Donzé-Baume, as I said before we worked overtime until December and today we have a workload below 50%. That workload of course, is also partially caused by external customers, including the Swatch Group – including the Swatch Group who has also reduced their demands of supply drastically to do what we are doing to manage inventories.

However, painful that is, we had to downsize some of these operations because we think this demand will not at first be covered. However, when we do this, we look very much at not losing the people who have the specific know-how, Stern for instance is a company which makes extremely sophisticated dials, it's the company in the industry and we have to be very careful to balance adjustments, to capacity, and at the same time not losing know-how, which we will need badly, when – and I say when, not if, when the upswing comes.

And therefore, and the Chairman mentioned it before working time, which we have prophylactically in place for all our Maisons, not yet executed for all our Maisons, but prophylactically in place is a great tool to do that. This concept, as you probably already know also works in Germany and that's also in place for Montblanc and we will call month-to-month to look at the development and decide the appropriate measures.

That might lead to extended summer holidays here in Switzerland. As you know, I have never understood this as a German, why we need to close factories for three, four weeks, but in Switzerland that's a history you cannot work against. Now, it's an opportunity to extend this and if we need to do that. It's not decided yet, but we will do it if we have to. And again why because over supply is the worst what can happen in a luxury business. Besides all the consequences for your own cash flow, for our stock risks, and so on and so forth.

Of course, last year, we had still, very vibrant discussions to build all these factories, you wanted us to build, of course, we have stopped all these projects for the time being, for the time being. In October, we froze instantly all non- strategic CapEx, of course, that does not change our few and long potential of the industry. For the time being, we will limit our investments, Richard mentioned it already to two strategic projects; SAP, and selective boutique openings mostly in Asia-Pacific.

We opened in the year 59 stores and invested €60 million in Asia-Pacific and Middle-East; 40 million were invested mainly in China and Richard again mentioned that I think we have today a meaningful presence in China specifically with in excess of 60 stores in China, Montblanc in excess of 40, and Cartier in excess of 30.

But that shouldn't – we will limit CapEx to R&D. But of course, we will continue R&D. R&D is future engineers and people whose creative ideas are the future of the company. It would be almost like shooting yourself in the foot and trying to run 100 meters below 10 seconds to save even $0.01 in that area. We will have to finish the manufacturing extension of Jaeger-LeCoultre, which had been started in the good times and that's ongoing.

I talked about hiring fees. If you look at our fixed cost, 50% of the fixed cost is related to people so hiring fees is a useful exercise not loved by my colleagues, now more accepted. Meanwhile more accepted by my colleagues. As a result of this freeze, we did not hire 1,700 people who were originally budgeted. So we have therefore reduced significantly head count against budget and we hedge to adjust unfortunately although by some layoffs our staff in the U.S. and in – selectively in Japan.

As I mentioned before specifically in our component manufacturing entities, which work for the firms, but also for competitors as I mentioned, we had to adjust production capacities and that cost layoffs in the order of 300 people. We have decided that there will be no salary raise for non-union staffs this year, in other words only legally entitled contracted people who are entitled to this will have salary increase, everybody else not.

We have decided that the option program this year will not be rewarded to management, it will however rewarded to executives, I mean, these guys after all do the work not the big engines right and when you are freezing salaries, when previous options are underwater at least the people in the trenches who do the work need to be seeing that the company is interested in their long future and that's why we continue this program but not for top management.

As Richard already mentioned in excess of 60 stores will be closed throughout last year and this year and again we will look as the business develops whether it has to stay that way or whether we have to take further measures depending on the future sales.

Communication expenses have been properly monitored. You have seen that communication increased, but that is out to the second SIHH mainly, which we had to have in this one year where we move the SIHH to Geneva here followed by three months to January.

Finally, and that is a very, very interesting exercise. We are renegotiating all fee-related contracts. That includes contracts for offices. In some countries that is not possible, my people tell me. Totally not true, it's all always possible to renegotiate and we have some considerable first successes in doing that and we will continue to do that.
